unnormalised: Someone asked me about IP rights in India, so here’s a quick rundown.
normalised: Someone asked me about I-P rights in India, so here is a quick rundown.

unnormalised: Firstly, Intellectual Property (IP) in India is governed by several laws. For patents, it's the Patents Act, 1970. Copyright falls under the Copyright Act, 1957. Trademarks are covered by the Trade Marks Act, 1999. Design protection is through the Designs Act, 2000. Geographical Indications (GI) are protected under the Geographical Indications of Goods (Registration & Protection) Act, 1999. Don't forget, these Acts are amended from time to time. For example, the Copyright Act was last amended in 2012.
normalised: Firstly, Intellectual Property (I-P) in India is governed by several laws. For patents, it's the Patents Act, one thousand nine hundred and seventy. Copyright falls under the Copyright Act, one thousand nine hundred and fifty seven. Trademarks are covered by the Trade Marks Act, one thousand nine hundred and ninety nine. Design protection is through the Designs Act, two thousand. Geographical Indications (G-I) are protected under the Geographical Indications of Goods (Registration and Protection) Act, one thousand nine hundred and ninety nine. Don't forget, these Acts are amended from time to time. For example, the Copyright Act was last amended in two thousand and twelve.

unnormalised: The process for securing these rights varies. For a patent, you need to file an application with the Indian Patent Office, and this can cost anywhere from Rs. 1600 to Rs. 4000 depending on whether you are an individual, small entity or large entity. The entire process, including examination and grant, can take 3-5 yrs. For trademark registration, the initial filing fee is around Rs. 4500. Copyright registration is comparatively simpler, costing around Rs. 500 per work. Each IP has a term of validity. Patents are typically valid for 20 yrs from the date of filing. Trademarks can be renewed indefinitely, every 10 yrs. Copyright lasts for the lifetime of the author plus 60 yrs.
normalised: The process for securing these rights varies. For a patent, you need to file an application with the Indian Patent Office, and this can cost anywhere from rupee one thousand six hundred to rupee four thousand depending on whether you are an individual, small entity or large entity. The entire process, including examination and grant, can take three to five years. For trademark registration, the initial filing fee is around rupee four thousand five hundred. Copyright registration is comparatively simpler, costing around rupee five hundred per work. Each I-P has a term of validity. Patents are typically valid for twenty years from the date of filing. Trademarks can be renewed indefinitely, every ten years. Copyright lasts for the lifetime of the author plus sixty years.

unnormalised: Infringement of IP rights can have serious consequences. For example, violating a patent can lead to injunctions preventing further use and damages to compensate the patent holder. Copyright infringement can result in imprisonment and fines, as per Section 63 of the Copyright Act, 1957. Counterfeiting trademarks also carries significant penalties. Remember the case of Bata India Ltd. vs Chawla Boot House (2018), where the defendant was penalized for using a deceptively similar trademark?

unnormalised: So, if you’re planning to launch a new product or service, it’s wise to consult with an IP lawyer. Protecting your IP is crucial for safeguarding your business interests in India. Don't wait until it's too late and someone copies your hard work, especially considering the number of IP violation cases reported every year.
